
[TITLE]
<line: 2> IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
<line: 3> FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA

[TEXT]
<line: 5> FORTUNATA MORALES LOPEZ
<line: 6> c/o 519 H Street NW
<line: 7> Washington, DC 20001

[TEXT]
<line: 9> GRICELDA MORALES CASARRUBIA
<line: 10> c/o 519 H Street NW
<line: 11> Washington, DC 20001

<line: 13> Plaintiffs,

[TEXT]
<line: 15> Civil Action No.

[TEXT]
<line: 17> v.

[TEXT]
<line: 19> PIASSA, INC
<line: 20> d/b/a PIASSA
<line: 21> 1336 9th Street NW
<line: 22> Washington, DC 20001

[TEXT]
<line: 24> JOSEPH TESHOME
<line: 25> 6611 Castle Bar Court
<line: 26> Alexandria, VA 22315

[TEXT]
<line: 28> YODIT EGIZEABHIR
<line: 29> a/k/a YODIT LULU
<line: 30> a/k/a YODIT TESHOME
<line: 31> 6611 Castle Bar Court
<line: 32> Alexandria, VA 22315

[TEXT]
<line: 34> Defendants.

[TITLE]
<line: 36> COMPLAINT

[TEXT]
<line: 38> 1.
<line: 39> Defendants employed Plaintiffs at their restaurant, "Piassa." Defendants engaged in a
<line: 40> number of unlawful pay practices with respect to Plaintiffs.

[TEXT]
<line: 42> 2.
<line: 43> First: Defendants did not pay overtime. Second: at times, Defendants paid Plaintiffs an.
<line: 44> hourly rate that was less than the District of Columbia's minimum wage. Third: Defendants did
<line: 45> not pay Plaintiff Fortunata Morales Lopez for her final weeks of work. And fourth: Defendants
<line: 46> did not provide Plaintiffs with legally-mandated paid safe and sick leave.

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 3. 
<line: 3> Plaintiffs bring this action to recover damages for Defendants’ willful failure to pay 
<line: 4> overtime wages, in violation of the Fair Labor Standards Act (“FLSA”), 29 U.S.C. § 201 et seq.; 
<line: 5> for Defendants’ willful failure to pay regular, minimum, and overtime wages, in violation of the 
<line: 6> District of Columbia Wage Payment and Collection Law (“DCWPCL”), D.C. Code § 32-1301 et 
<line: 7> seq.; and for Defendants' failure to provide safe and sick leave, pursuant to the District of 
<line: 8> Columbia Accrued Safe and Sick Leave Act ("ASSLA"), D.C. Code § 32-131.01 et seq. 

[TITLE]
<line: 10> Jurisdiction and Venue 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 4. 
<line: 13> Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1331 (federal question jurisdiction) and 28 
<line: 14> U.S.C. § 1367 (supplemental jurisdiction). 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 5. 
<line: 17> Venue is proper pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b) because a substantial part of the events 
<line: 18> or omissions giving rise to Plaintiffs’ claims occurred in this district. 

[TITLE]
<line: 20> Parties 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> 6. 
<line: 23> Plaintiff Fortunata Morales Lopez is an adult resident of the District of Columbia. 
<line: 24> 7. 
<line: 25> Plaintiff Gricelda Morales Casarrubia is an adult resident of the District of Columbia. 
<line: 26> 8. 
<line: 27> Defendant Piassa, Inc. is a District of Columbia corporate entity. Piassa, Inc. did business 
<line: 28> as Piassa, a restaurant located at 1336 9th Street NW, Washington, DC 20001. Piassa, Inc.’s 
<line: 29> resident agent for service of process is Joseph Teshome, 1336 9th Street NW, Washington, DC 
<line: 30> 20001. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 9. 
<line: 33> Defendant Joseph Teshome is an adult resident of Virginia. He resides at 1336 9th Street 
<line: 34> NW, Washington, DC 20001. He is an owner and the managing member of Defendant Piassa, 
<line: 35> Inc. At all relevant times, Defendant Teshome held and exercised authority over the operations 
<line: 36> of Piassa, Inc — including its pay practices. 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> 10. 
<line: 39> Defendant Yodit Egizeabhir is an adult resident of Virginia. She resides at 1336 9th 
<line: 40> Street NW, Washington, DC 20001. She is also known as Yodit Lulu and Yodit Teshome. She is 

[ABANDON]
<line: 42> 2 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> an owner and the managing member of Defendant Piassa, Inc. At all relevant times, Defendant
<line: 3> Egizeabhir held and exercised authority over the operations of Piassa, Inc - including its pay
<line: 4> practices.

[TEXT]
<line: 6> 11.
<line: 7> Upon information and belief, Defendants Joseph Teshome and Yodit Egizeabhir are
<line: 8> husband and wife.

[TITLE]
<line: 10> Factual Allegations Specific to Plaintiff Morales Lopez.

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 12.
<line: 13> Plaintiff Morales Lopez worked at Piassa from approximately July 1, 2015 through
<line: 14> approximately December 3, 2016.

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 13.
<line: 17> Plaintiff Morales Lopez worked as a kitchen hand..

[TEXT]
<line: 19> 14.
<line: 20> Plaintiff Morales Lopez's job duties primarily consisted of cutting vegetables and meats,
<line: 21> preparing sauces, cooking, and cleaning

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 15.
<line: 24> Plaintiff Morales Lopez typically and customarily worked more than 40 hours per
<line: 25> workweek.

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 16.
<line: 28> Until October 29, 2016, Plaintiff Morales Lopez typically and customarily worked seven
<line: 29> days a week.

[TEXT]
<line: 31> 17.
<line: 32> Until October 29, 2016, Plaintiff Morales Lopez typically and customarily worked the
<line: 33> following schedule:

[TABLE]
<line: 35> Entry and Exit Time
<line: 36>  Break Time
<line: 37> Hours Worked
<line: 38>  Sunday
<line: 39> 7:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m.
<line: 40> None
<line: 41> 8.0 Hours
<line: 42>  Monday
<line: 43> 7:00 a.m. - 2:30 p.m.
<line: 44> None
<line: 45> 7.5 Hours
<line: 46>  Tuesday
<line: 47> 7:00 a.m. - 2:30 p.m.
<line: 48> None
<line: 49> 7.5 Hours
<line: 50> Wednesday
<line: 51> 7:00 a.m. - 2:30 p.m.
<line: 52> None
<line: 53> 7.5 Hours
<line: 54> Thursday
<line: 55> 7:00 a.m. - 2:30 p.m.
<line: 56> None
<line: 57> 7.5 Hours
<line: 58>  Friday
<line: 59> 7:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 60> None
<line: 61> 9.0 Hours
<line: 62>  Saturday
<line: 63> 7:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 64> None
<line: 65> 9.0 Hours
<line: 66> Total Hours
<line: 67> 56.0 Hours

[TEXT]
<line: 69> 18.
<line: 70> Until October 29, 2016, Plaintiff Morales Lopez typically worked 56 hours a week.

[ABANDON]
<line: 72> 3

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 19. 
<line: 3> Until October 29, 2016, Plaintiff Morales Lopez was always paid $10.50 per hour 
<line: 4> (including after July 1, 2016, when the D.C. minimum wage increased to $11.50). 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> 20. 
<line: 7> Plaintiff Morales Lopez was never paid overtime wages for when she worked more than 
<line: 8> 40 hours in a workweek. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 21. 
<line: 11> Plaintiff Morales Lopez was always paid her regular hourly rate across all of her hours 
<line: 12> worked, including when she worked more than 40 hours in a workweek. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> 22. 
<line: 15> Starting on approximately October 29, 2016, Defendants reduced Plaintiff Morales 
<line: 16> Lopez's work schedule. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 23. 
<line: 19> From October 29, 2016 through December 23, 2016, Plaintiff Morales Lopez worked 150 
<line: 20> hours, including four overtime hours. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> 24. 
<line: 23> For her work after October 29, 2016, Plaintiff Morales Lopez was not paid anything. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> 25. 
<line: 26> On November 17, 2016, Defendants tendered Plaintiff Morales Lopez a check for 
<line: 27> $735.00. However, the check bounced for lack of funds. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 26. 
<line: 30> At all relevant times, Plaintiff Morales Lopez was paid semimonthly. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 27. 
<line: 33> Plaintiff Morales Lopez was typically paid by check. However, Defendants occasionally 
<line: 34> paid her with cash. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 28. 
<line: 37> Defendants owe Plaintiff Morales Lopez approximately $8,598.50 in unpaid regular, 
<line: 38> minimum, and overtime wages. 

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 29. 
<line: 41> Moreover, Defendants never provided Plaintiff Morales Lopez with paid safe and sick 
<line: 42> leave, as required by the ASSLA. 

[TEXT]
<line: 44> 30. 
<line: 45> Defendants should have provided Plaintiff Morales Lopez with 2.09 days of paid leave in 
<line: 46> 2015 and 3.00 days of paid leave in 2016, with each day of paid leave equal to eight hours of 
<line: 47> paid leave. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 49> 4 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 31.
<line: 3> Plaintiff Morales Lopez was sick for several days in both 2015 and 2016, so she lost.
<line: 4> wages as a result of Defendants' failure to provide paid leave.

[TEXT]
<line: 6> 32.
<line: 7> For Defendants' failure to provide paid leave, Defendants owe Plaintiff Morales Lopez.
<line: 8> approximately $2,973.70 in lost wages and compensatory damages.

[TITLE]
<line: 10> Factual Allegations Specific to Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia.

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 33.
<line: 13> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia worked at Piassa from approximately July 1, 2015 through
<line: 14> approximately December 15, 2015.

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 34.
<line: 17> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia worked as a kitchen hand..

[TEXT]
<line: 19> 35.
<line: 20> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia's job duties primarily consisted of preparing coffee, cutting
<line: 21> vegetables and meats, working as a cashier, bussing tables, and cleaning.

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 36.
<line: 24> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia typically and customarily worked more than 40 hours per
<line: 25> workweek.

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 37.
<line: 28> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia typically and customarily worked seven days a week.

[TEXT]
<line: 30> 38.
<line: 31> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia's official schedule was as follows:

[TABLE]
<line: 33> Entry and Exit Time.
<line: 34> Break Time
<line: 35> Hours Worked.
<line: 36>  Sunday
<line: 37> 7:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 38>  None
<line: 39> 9.0 Hours
<line: 40>  Monday
<line: 41> 7:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 42> None
<line: 43> 9.0 Hours
<line: 44> Tuesday
<line: 45> 7:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 46> None
<line: 47> 9.0 Hours
<line: 48> Wednesday
<line: 49> 7:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 50> None
<line: 51> 9.0 Hours
<line: 52> Thursday
<line: 53> 7:00 a.m. -
<line: 54> - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 55> None
<line: 56> 9.0 Hours
<line: 57> Friday
<line: 58> 7:00 a.m. -
<line: 59>  4:00 p.m.
<line: 60> None
<line: 61> 9.0 Hours
<line: 62>  Saturday
<line: 63> 7:00 a.m. -
<line: 64> - 4:00 p.m.
<line: 65>  None
<line: 66> 9.0 Hours
<line: 67> Total Hours
<line: 68> 63.0 Hours

[TEXT]
<line: 70> 39.
<line: 71> However, for at least three days a week, Defendants told Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia to
<line: 72> work an additional five hours, until 9:00 p.m. rather than 4:00 p.m.

[TEXT]
<line: 74> 40.
<line: 75> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia typically and customarily worked 78 hours a week.

[TEXT]
<line: 77> 41.
<line: 78> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia was paid at the following hourly rates:

[ABANDON]
<line: 80> 5

[TABLE]
<line: 2> Approximate Dates
<line: 3> Hourly Rate.
<line: 4> Jul. 1, 2015 - Sept. 29, 2015
<line: 5> $9.50
<line: 6> Sept. 30, 2015 - Dec. 15, 2015
<line: 7> $10.50

[TEXT]
<line: 9> 42.
<line: 10> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia was never paid overtime wages for when she worked more
<line: 11> than 40 hours in a workweek.

[TEXT]
<line: 13> 43.
<line: 14> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia earned her regular hourly rate across all of her hours
<line: 15> worked, including when she worked more than 40 hours in a workweek.

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 44.
<line: 18> At all relevant times, Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia was paid semimonthly.

[TEXT]
<line: 20> 45.
<line: 21> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia was typically paid by check. However, Defendants
<line: 22> occasionally paid her with cash.

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 46.
<line: 25> Defendants owe Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia approximately $6,163.00 in unpaid
<line: 26> minimum and overtime wages.

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 47.
<line: 29> Moreover, Defendants never provided Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia with paid safe and
<line: 30> sick leave, as required by the ASSLA.

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 48.
<line: 33> Defendants should have provided Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia with 2.91 days of paid
<line: 34> leave in 2015, with each day of paid leave equal to eight hours of paid leave..

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 49.
<line: 37> Plaintiff Morales Casarrubia was sick for several days in both 2015 and 2016, so she lost
<line: 38> wages as a result of Defendants' failure to provide paid leave.

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 50.
<line: 41> For Defendants' failure to provide paid leave, Defendants owe Plaintiff Morales
<line: 42> Casarrubia approximately $1,701.66 in lost wages and compensatory damages.

[TITLE]
<line: 44> Factual Allegations Common to All Plaintiffs

[TEXT]
<line: 46> 51.
<line: 47> At all relevant times, Defendants had the power to hire and fire Plaintiffs..
<line: 48> 52.
<line: 49> At all relevant times, Defendants had the power to control Plaintiffs' work schedule.
<line: 50> 53.
<line: 51> At all relevant times, Defendants had the power to supervise and control Plaintiffs' work
<line: 52> 54.
<line: 53> At all relevant times, Defendants had the power to set Plaintiffs' rate and manner of pay.

[ABANDON]
<line: 55> 6

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 55. 
<line: 3> At all relevant times, Plaintiffs' paychecks were signed by either Joseph Theshome or 
<line: 4> Yodit Egizeabhir. 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> 56. 
<line: 7> Defendants Joseph Theshome and Yodit Egizeabhir personally hired Plaintiffs. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> 57. 
<line: 10> At all relevant times, Defendants were aware that they were legally required to pay 
<line: 11> Plaintiffs one and one-half times Plaintiffs' regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of 
<line: 12> 40 hours in any one workweek. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> 58. 
<line: 15> At all relevant times, Defendants were aware that they were legally required to pay 
<line: 16> Plaintiffs the applicable minimum wage. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 59. 
<line: 19> At all relevant times, Defendants were aware that they were required to provide paid safe 
<line: 20> and sick leave pursuant to the ASSLA. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> 60. 
<line: 23> The District of Columbia minimum wage was $10.50 per hour from July 1, 2015 through 
<line: 24> June 30, 2016, and $11.50 per hour from July 1, 2016 through the present. D.C. Code § 32-
<line: 25> 1003(a). 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 61. 
<line: 28> At all relevant times, Defendants did not provide Plaintiffs with paid leave pursuant to 
<line: 29> the ASSLA. Plaintiffs were required to work for Defendants, irrespective of whether or not 
<line: 30> Plaintiffs were sick. If Plaintiffs took time off because of illness or the illness of a family 
<line: 31> member, they were not paid for that time. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> 62. 
<line: 34> At all relevant times, Defendants had less than 25 employees. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 63. 
<line: 37> At all relevant times, the annual gross volume of Defendants' business exceeded 
<line: 38> $500,000.00. 

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 64. 
<line: 41> At all relevant times, Defendants had two or more employees who handled goods and/or 
<line: 42> materials that had travelled in or been produced for interstate commerce. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 44> 7 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> COUNT I 

[TITLE]
<line: 4> FAILURE TO PAY OVERTIME WAGES UNDER THE FLSA 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> 65. 
<line: 7> Plaintiffs incorporate the foregoing paragraphs as if fully restated herein. 
<line: 8> 66. 
<line: 9> Each defendant was an “employer” of Plaintiffs within the meaning of the FLSA. 29 
<line: 10> U.S.C. § 203(d). 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 67. 
<line: 13> The FLSA requires employers to pay non-exempt employees one and one-half times their 
<line: 14> regular hourly rate for hours worked in excess of 40 hours in any one workweek. 29 U.S.C. § 
<line: 15> 207(a)(1). 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 68. 
<line: 18> Defendants violated the FLSA by knowingly failing to pay Plaintiffs at least one and one-
<line: 19> half times Plaintiffs’ regular hourly rates for hours worked in excess of 40 hours in any one 
<line: 20> workweek. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> 69. 
<line: 23> Defendants’ violations of the FLSA were willful. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> 70. 
<line: 26> For Defendants’ violations of the FLSA, Defendants are liable to Plaintiffs for unpaid 
<line: 27> overtime wages, an equal amount as liquidated damages, court costs, reasonable attorney’s fees 
<line: 28> and expenses, interest, and any other relief deemed appropriate by the Court. 

[TITLE]
<line: 30> COUNT II 

[TITLE]
<line: 32> FAILURE TO PAY WAGES UNDER THE DCWPCL 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> 71. 
<line: 35> Plaintiffs incorporate the foregoing paragraphs as if fully restated herein. 
<line: 36> 72. 
<line: 37> Each defendant was an “employer” of Plaintiffs within the meaning of the DCWPCL. 
<line: 38> D.C. Code § 32-1301(1). 
<line: 39> 73. 
<line: 40> The DCWPCL requires employers to pay an employee who is discharged no later than 
<line: 41> the working day following the discharge. D.C. Code § 32-1303(1). 

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> 8 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 74.
<line: 3> The DCwPCL requires employers to pay an employee who quits or resigns all wages due
<line: 4> upon the next regular payday, or within 7 days from the date of quitting or resigning, whichever
<line: 5> is earlier. D.C. Code $ 32-1303(2)

[TEXT]
<line: 7> 75.
<line: 8> For purposes of the DCWPCL, "wages" include, among other things, minimum and.
<line: 9> overtime wages. D.C Code $ 32-1301(3).

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 76.
<line: 12>  Defendants violated the DCwPCL by knowingly failing to timely pay Plaintiffs all wages
<line: 13> earned, including regular, minimum, and overtime wages..

[TEXT]
<line: 15> 77.
<line: 16> Defendants' violations of the DCWPCL were willful..

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 78.
<line: 19> For Defendants' violations of the DCwPCL, Defendants are liable to Plaintiffs for
<line: 20> unpaid wages, an amount equal to three times the amount of unpaid wages as liquidated
<line: 21> damages, court costs, reasonable attorney's fees and expenses, interest, and any other relief
<line: 22> deemed appropriate by the Court.

[TITLE]
<line: 24> COUNT III

[TITLE]
<line: 26> FAILURE TO PROVIDE SICK LEAVE UNDER THE ASSLA

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 79.
<line: 29> Plaintiffs incorporate the foregoing paragraphs as if fully restated herein..
<line: 30> 80.
<line: 31> Each defendant was an "employer' of Plaintiffs within the meaning of the ASSLA. D.C..
<line: 32> Code $ 32-131.01.

[TEXT]
<line: 34> 81.
<line: 35> The ASSLA requires the following amounts of paid leave.

[TABLE]
<line: 37> Maximum Provision
<line: 38> Size of Employer
<line: 39> Provision of Paid Leave
<line: 40> Per Calendar Year
<line: 41> 100 or more employees
<line: 42> 1 hour for every 37 hours worked
<line: 43> 7 days
<line: 44> 25 to 99 employees
<line: 45> 1 hour for every 43 hours worked
<line: 46> 5 days
<line: 47> 24 or fewer employees
<line: 48> 3 days
<line: 49> 1 hour for every 87 hours worked

[TEXT]
<line: 51> D.C. Code s 32-131.02(a).

[TEXT]
<line: 53> 82.
<line: 54> Defendants violated the ASSLA by not providing Plaintiffs with the required paid leave..

[ABANDON]
<line: 56> 9

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 83. 
<line: 3> Defendants willfully violated the ASSLA — and showed a wanton disregard for both the 
<line: 4> ASSLA and its public policy justifications. When a restaurant requires workers who handle food 
<line: 5> to be present when they are sick, it endangers the public. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> 84. 
<line: 8> For Defendants’ violations of the ASSLA, Defendants are liable to Plaintiffs for $500 in 
<line: 9> additional damages for each accrued day of leave denied, regardless of whether Plaintiffs took 
<line: 10> unpaid leave or reported to work on that day. D.C. Code § 32-131.12(b).  

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 85. 
<line: 13> For Defendants' violations of the ASSLA, Defendants are liable for back pay for lost 
<line: 14> wages, compensatory damages, punitive damages, court costs, reasonable attorney’s fees and 
<line: 15> expenses, and any other relief deemed appropriate by the Court. D.C. Code § 32-131.12(e). 

[TITLE]
<line: 17> PRAYER FOR RELIEF 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs respectfully request that this Court enter judgment against 
<line: 20> Defendants, on all counts, jointly and severally, in the current total amount of $77,276.51, and 
<line: 21> grant the following relief: 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> a. 
<line: 24> Award Plaintiffs $59,046.00, consisting of the following overlapping elements: 
<line: 25> i. 
<line: 26> unpaid overtime wages, plus an equal amount as liquidated damages, 
<line: 27> pursuant to the FLSA, 29 U.S.C. § 216; 
<line: 28> ii. 
<line: 29> unpaid regular, minimum, and overtime wages, plus three times the 
<line: 30> amount of unpaid wages as liquidated damages, pursuant to the DCWPCL, 
<line: 31> D.C. Code §§ 32-1303(4) and 32-1308; 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> b. 
<line: 34> Award Plaintiffs $9,675.36, consisting of the following: 
<line: 35> i. 
<line: 36> $672.48 in lost wages and compensatory damages for  
<line: 37> denied paid leave, pursuant to the ASSLA, D.C. Code § 32-131.02(e); 
<line: 38> ii.  
<line: 39> $4,002.87 in additional damages for each day of denied paid leave,  
<line: 40> pursuant to the ASSLA, D.C. Code § 32-131.12(b); 

[ABANDON]
<line: 42> 10 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> iii. 
<line: 3>  $5,000.00 in punitive damages, pursuant to the ASSLA, D.C. Code § 32- 
<line: 4> 131.12(e). 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> c. 
<line: 7> Award Plaintiffs pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as permitted by law. 
<line: 8> d. 
<line: 9> Award Plaintiffs attorney’s fees and expenses computed pursuant to the matrix 
<line: 10> approved in Salazar v. District of Columbia, 123 F. Supp. 2d 8 (D.D.C. 2000), and 
<line: 11> updated to account for the current market hourly rates for attorney's services, pursuant to 
<line: 12> D.C. Code § 32-1308(b)(1) (as of this date, approximately $8,155.15);  
<line: 13> e. 
<line: 14> Award Plaintiffs court costs (currently, $400.00); and 
<line: 15> f. 
<line: 16> Award any additional relief the Court deems just. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> Date: February 2, 2017 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> Respectfully submitted, 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> /s/ Justin Zelikovitz, Esq. 
<line: 23> Justin Zelikovitz, #986001 
<line: 24> DCWageLaw

<line: 26> Washington, DC 20001

[TEXT]
<line: 31> Counsel for Plaintiffs 

[TITLE]
<line: 33> JURY DEMAND 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> Plaintiffs hereby demand a trial by jury as to all issues so triable. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> /s/ Justin Zelikovitz, Esq. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> 11
